I.    Introduction

An Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) 29 CFR 1910.119 "Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals" and an Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) 40 CFR 68 "Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions" plan has been developed for the  the Baxter Healthcare Corporation (Baxter) facility located at 1900 Highway 201 N in Mountain Home, Arkansas, for the reduction of accidental releases of hazardous materials. This OSHA PSM / EPA RMP program summarizes the management, administrative, procedural, and technological controls that work together to minimize the risk to site personnel, contractors, visitors, and the community and environment at large of hazardous chemical releases. The OSHA PSM / EPA RMP program is organized to correspond with specific EPARMP, Program 3 requirements.  

II.    Baxter Healthcare Policies To Protect Health, Environment, and Safety

Risk management and safety are important concerns at Baxter. Baxter is committed to conducting its operations in a safe and responsible manner and to reducing risks to human health and to the environment. It is Baxter's policy to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local rules and regulations.



Baxter's OSHA PSM / EPA RMP program  has identified potential hazards related to our ethylene oxide process and has taken steps to design and maintain a safe facility in order to prevent releases, and minimize the consequences of accidental releases, which could occur. OSHA PSM / EPA RMP addresses potentially catastrophic chemical releases that could result in immediate harm and acute health effects to offsite receptors (public and environmental). Baxter has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that contains procedures designed to maximize the safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences.



III.    Facility Identification

The Baxter facility is located at 1900 Highway 201 N in Mountain H

ome, Arkansas. Baxter is a hospital products and pharmaceutical manufacturer specializing in IV solutions and premixed drugs, IV infusion pumps and administration sets, parenteral nutrition, etc.



The NAICS code for the facility is 325412. The facility uses ethylene oxide for product sterilization, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. 



400 pound cylinders of ethylene oxide are used for each sterilization vessel. There are a total of seven (7) sterilization vessels used at one time, resulting in 2800 pounds of ethylene oxide "on-line" at any given time. However, the sterilization lines are individually piped to each sterilization vessel. Therefore, a release of one (1) ethylene oxide cylinder is not expected to result in a release to the other cylinders. 



An aerial map identifying the site location is included as Appendix A. 



IV.    Hazard Assessment - Worse Case Scenarios (WCS)

Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the worst-case scenario. Appendix C consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the worse case release scenario. 



V.    Hazard Assessment - Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS)

Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the alternative release scenario. Appendix D consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the alternative release scenario. 



VI.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   



This prevention program covers those processes that utilize ethylene oxide above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. 



VII.    Five-Year Accident History

The Baxter facility has not experienced an accidental ethylene oxide release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant pr

operty damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



VIII.    Emergency Response Program

Baxter has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. 



Baxter has communicated and trained facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and has interacted (i.e. onsite inspections) with the Mountain Home Fire Department. 



Baxter has coordinated their EAP with the Mountain Home Fire Department.  This coordination effort includes providing the agency with a copy of our EAP, and providing a site diagram and hazardous material information, meeting with Mountain Home Fire Department personnel to discuss the facility's operations/processes, and encouraging periodic on-site inspections and coordination with Mountain Home Fire Department personnel.



Currently, Baxter does not have designated personnel as members of a hazardous materials response team. The facility will rely on response by the Mountain Home Fire Department and HAZMAT Team, in the event of a ethylene oxide release.



The facility utilizes a windsock onsite to determine wind direction in the event of an ethylene oxide release and evacuation of the building.  The windsock is located on the EO Shed. 



The current Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for ethylene oxide is included in Appendix E. 



IX.    Emergency Communications

The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.



X.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Chemical safety is an important part of Baxter's operations. Baxter is committed to implementation of the written OSHA PSM/EPA RMP management program that address potential hazards of the ethylene oxide process. 



XI.    Management  System

Baxter has developed a management syst

em that identifies qualified person or position that have the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the process safety management / risk management program elements. If any portion of the OSHA PSM / EPA RMP program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals are defined within each OSHA PSM / EPA RMP program element. Currently, Joseph Belvedresi, Environmental & Safety Associate, is responsible for implementation of the overall OSHA PSM / EPA RMP program.
